Data Visualization

New York City Arrests, 2006 - present

By Crime

It is important to get an understanding of what types of crimes are commonly committed in New York City, the area we are currently looking at. Below is a table containing counts of all crimes committed over the period of 2006 - 2022, sorted in descending order. The most common crime committed over that time period was assault in the third degree (the lowest level of assault), followed by marijuana possession 4 & 5 (differentiated by the amount of marijuana possessed).

pd_desc total
ASSAULT 3 460078
MARIJUANA, POSSESSION 4 & 5 423783
THEFT OF SERVICES, UNCLASSIFIED 303359
CONTROLLED SUBSTANCE, POSSESSION 7 278083
NY STATE LAWS,UNCLASSIFIED VIOLATION 225678
ASSAULT 2,1,UNCLASSIFIED 197972
LARCENY,PETIT FROM OPEN AREAS,UNCLASSIFIED 188347
TRAFFIC,UNCLASSIFIED INFRACTION 165647
STOLEN PROPERTY 3,POSSESSION 153572
TRAFFIC,UNCLASSIFIED MISDEMEAN 147326
ROBBERY,UNCLASSIFIED,OPEN AREAS 143263
TRESPASS 3, CRIMINAL 114998
INTOXICATED DRIVING,ALCOHOL 114729
CONTROLLED SUBSTANCE,INTENT TO SELL 3 113538
WEAPONS, POSSESSION, ETC 103913

Lets look at how each of these crimes is changing over time.

This graph includes the eight most common types of arrests made over the time period. Some interesting patterns reveal themselves when the data are categorized as such, particularly the arrests for marijuana possession. They spike around 2011 but then drop off quickly and today are non-existent. This is an excellent example to use to observe the effect that real-world events have on the trends we observe here. In 2014, New York City mayor Bill de Blasio told the NYPD to stop arrests for marijuana possession and instead issue tickets in attempts to decriminalize marijuana (Dizard 2014). A drop in arrests is clearly seen around that time period. Around the same time, New York Governor Andrew Cuomo signed legislation which would allow the use of cannabis for medicinal purposes (Campbell 2014). Then, in 2021, recreational cannabis was legalized for adults over 21, up to a specific amount. Since then, the NYPD has not listed any crime related to marijuana, as evidenced by there being no arrests for possession on the graph past 2021.

References

Campbell, Jon. 2014. “Cuomo Signs New York’s Medical Marijuana Bill.” USA Today. USA Today. https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2014/07/07/cuomo-signs-medical-marijuana-bill/12323967/.
Dizard, Wilson. 2014. “NYC Decides Pot Fines Are Just the Ticket.” Al Jazeera America. Al Jazeera America. http://america.aljazeera.com/articles/2014/11/10/marijuana-ticketnewyork.html.
